3.1 The ethics of coercion

In section 3.3, we’ll consider how coercion is thought to
impinge upon freedom, something that raises obvious ethical
implications in its own right. So consideration of these sorts of
ethical issues will be postponed until there. The present section
looks at certain more basic questions about whether and why employing
coercion is necessarily or contingently wrongful, as well as whether
its wrongfulness is intrinsic to it or derivative, and what else might
be wrong with it besides its effect on freedom or autonomy.

There has been considerable debate over the question of whether
employing coercion is necessarily or contingently wrongful. There seem
to be three categories in which answers to this question might fall:
coercion is necessarily wrongful; it is prima facie or
pro tanto wrongful, though it may be justified by further
facts; and it is intrinsically morally neutral, though some uses of it
may be wrongful because of specific facts about them. Differences in
understanding what is wrongful about it may account for these
different positions. Further, in cases where coercion is wrongful, we
might distinguish two different ways of explaining the nature of its
wrongfulness. It might be a basic wrong, in that being coercive is
sufficient to justify the judgment that it is wrongful; or, otherwise,
we can explain its wrongfulness as deriving from some component
activity that is wrongful, so that coercion’s wrongfulness is
derivative, rather than
 basic.[17]

One route to finding coercion is necessarily wrongful is to define
coercion as constitutively involving a violation or threatened
violation of the coercee’s rights, or a proposal to violate
one’s normative obligations. For instance, Cheyney Ryan argues
for such a normative conception of coercion. (See Ryan 1980.) Tying
coercion closely to immoral action captures a number of intuitions we
have about coercion, reflecting also a lot of ordinary language.
People often associate uses of coercion with injustices done to
themselves or others. This tie also provides a sharper division
between coercive and non-coercive activity than might otherwise be
found: if an activity is morally unobjectionable, then it is ipso
facto not coercive.

If coercion is not necessarily wrongful, it might still involve moral
judgment by being defined as requiring some prima facie or
pro tanto immoral element; this is probably the most commonly
held view. There have been a variety of different attempts, especially
in the 21st century, to find and describe the immoral
factor in coercion that will then suffice to explain its wrongfulness
when not rebutted, while avoiding the miscategorization of cases.

One suggestion holds that what is distinctive about coercion and gives
it its moral character is that it involves an instrumental making of a
threat to do something wrongful. Following Niko Kolodny we might call
this the “inheritance” view (Kolodny 2017). For instance,
Mitchell Berman has argued that when a coercer threatens to do
something, the rightness or wrongness of the use of such a threat to
coerce depends on whether it would be rightful or wrongful for that
agent to carry through with that threat (Berman 2002; see also Haksar
1976; Wertheimer 1987, ch. 12). Berman’s account of wrongful
coercion thus apparently relies on a principle of inference that holds
that if it is wrong to do A, then it is wrong to
threaten to do A, and vice versa. Japa
Pallikkathayil sketches a similar view, holding that if the
coercer’s proposal has motivational force only because it
proposes to do something that the recipient should have a right to
veto, then such a proposal (in at least paradigmatic cases of
coercion) wrongfully constrains the recipient, and wrongfully impinges
on their normative powers. Here too, the wrongfulness of the proposal
depends on the wrongfulness of the thing the coercer proposes to do
(Pallikkathayil 2011). Benjamin Sachs suggests a claim that might
bolster Berman’s position, namely, that the very making of the
threat has the tendency to increase the likelihood that the threatener
will carry out the wrongful act threatened, which he describes as
“self-incitement” (Sachs 2013). The
“inheritance” view is similarly defended by James Shaw
(2012), in his account of the immorality of blackmail.

The inheritance view does not seem to correctly categorize or explain
the morality of all cases that are intuitively regarded as coercive.
At least sometimes it appears appropriate to threaten to do something
which would be wrong to carry out (nuclear deterrence is sometimes
thought to be like this; see Section 4.1 below). And sometimes it may
be wrongful to threaten what it would be right to carry out (some
instances of blackmail and extortion seem to fit this description).
The inheritance view also does not explain why making a conditional
threat may be more ethically problematic than a plain,
unconditional
 threat.[18]
 Unfortunately, the complexities due particularly to the
conditionality of coercive threats have been little explored to date
by those more centrally interested in
 coercion.[19]

A second suggestion holds that there’s something special about
the coercer’s intention vis-à-vis the coercee that makes
coercion frequently problematic. Grant Lamond suggests that the
wrongness of wrongful coercion derives from the fact that it involves
a “proposal deliberately to impose a disadvantage on
another” (Lamond 2000, 49). “The distinctive wrong
involved in [coercive conditional] threats is to propose to take an
action because it is unwelcome to the recipient, i.e.,
because he does not want it done” (Lamond 1996, 228). It is thus
the coercer’s intention to harm or disadvantage the coercee (or
to propose to do so) that creates coercion’s special burden of
justification (though Lamond does not suppose such justifications are
particularly difficult to find). But it isn’t clear either that
when one proposes to harm another that one thereby intends to
bring about any harm (one could be
 bluffing).[20]
 More importantly, it’s also unclear that all intentions to
impose disadvantages are even prima facie in need of
justification. Unless we accept that all activities are prima
facie unjustified absent specific justifications, it requires an
argument to show that disadvantaging another person is itself
something that always must clear a hurdle to count as justified.
Certainly some kinds of disadvantage require special justification,
but some may not. One might, for instance, intend to disadvantage
one’s social rival by arranging to have him seated between two
dreary bores at a dinner party. While perhaps not nice, it seems to
require no special moral justification for this action (or the threat
of this action) to be ethically permissible. We might say that so long
as one respects the rights of others (a set as rich as one likes), one
needs no special justification to act towards them as one likes. And
surely no one has the right that no one else will ever act for the
sake of disadvantaging one. If this is the case, then the mere
intention to disadvantage someone, perhaps conditionally, does not
suffice to violate her rights.

Stephen White takes notice of the fact that sometimes we find coercion
problematic even if the coercer’s threat involves something that
it would not be wrongful for the coercer to do (White 2017). Cases of
blackmail, both conventional and “emotional blackmail,”
often have this form: the threatener threatens to do something they
may well have legal and moral right to do considered by itself, but
something that would not otherwise be tied to the actions of the
threat’s recipient. White argues that what coercers do in making
conditional threats is to make the coercee responsible for the
coercer’s execution of their threat, a responsibility that in
many cases they should not have to bear. This seems most clear in
cases where the coercer threatens to do something independently
wrongful, since they are obligated not to carry out such a threat, so
transferring that responsibility to the coercee is clearly wrongful.
But even if the act threatened, such as self-harm, is not
independently wrongful, forcing another to regard this outcome as
their responsibility to prevent generates an unfair burden. This
analysis is argued to help explain some other intuitions we have
regarding the threat of wrongful coercion to autonomy and its
deforming of the coercee’s choice situation.

Beyond wronging the target of coercion, there are arguably other
ethical implications of coercion. While acknowledging that the concept
of coercion is often invoked to play a role in “deontic”
judgments, identifying interpersonal wrongs, Michael Garnett aims to
expand the scope of our ethical concern with coercion by
distinguishing this deontic role from a principally
eudaimonistic role for a concept of coercion. Garnett argues
that coercion is bad for the individual insofar as it amounts to
one’s will being subjected to a foreign will—that of the
coercer—independently of whether the coercion is wrongful
(Garnett 2018; similar concerns with coercion are raised in Julius
2013 and Kolodny 2017). Similarly, Elinor Mason holds that coercion is
a kind of violation of agent integrity, by virtue of being subjected
to the domination of the coercer. She claims, “The coercer makes
a proposal to the coercee, and provides substantial reasons for the
coercee to do what the coercer desires. The coercer is attempting to
dominate the coercee: the coercer is not treating the coercee as an
agent, but as an object to be manipulated. The coercee finds the
proposal credible, and accepts the reasons provided as substantial. As
a result of the proposal, the coercee is dominated: she is alienated
from her action” (Mason 2012, 201). In a similar vein, Ambrose
Y. K. Lee argues that legal coercion used to incentivize people to do
what they have otherwise good reason to do already fails to respect
people as “reasons-responsive agents” (Lee 2014, 853). And
Jan-Willem van der Rijt suggests that it is a criterion of coercion
that the coercee feels subjectively wronged by it, thus making such
felt wrongness part of its essential meaning (van der Rijt 2011).

There are some situations in which the coerciveness of an action
appears obvious even though it may be difficult or impossible to
ascertain its rightfulness or wrongfulness. Thus some (e.g., Zimmerman
2002; Anderson 2010) have argued against making judgments of coercion
depend on prior moral judgments. For accounts of coercion that do not
invoke moral judgments to define it, the ethical implications of
coercion may be more contextual and determined by the particular uses
to which it is put. If one holds the common view that coercion is
rightly employed for purposes such as self-defense, defense of
innocent others, and the enforcement of just laws, such views may
encourage one to evaluate its use based on factors such as why and how
it is used, who uses it, against whom, in what circumstances, and what
other means were possible instead. Coercion is no ordinary means, but
if it can be defined in non-moralized terms, it’s unclear why we
should suppose that it is intrinsically (even prima facie or
pro tanto) immoral, instead of simply noting that it is a
very potent means, prone to abuse, and something that deserves ethical
scrutiny whenever it is used.
